docs.lead_paragraph: Ask Roy Lantigua what he wants to be when he grows up, and he will lay it all out, without a moment's hesitation. ''An archaeologist,'' he says confidently. ''Then I can go to Egypt.'' His favorite class in school is science, and he is eager to see mummies.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; From a Boy's Frail Body, An Intellect Bursts Out

docs.abstract: New Alternatives for Children, member of Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, buys home computer for Roy Lantigua, exceptionally gifted child with overwhelming physical disabilities; agency receives money from New York Times Neediest Cases fund; photo (M)

keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: In many respects, Michael Lagana is a typical 17-year-old. A junior at Dundalk High School in Maryland, he carries a full load of courses, loves playing football, and works after school selling newspaper subscriptions. He began smoking marijuana at 14. At 16, he was smoking three fat marijuana cigarettes a day or drinking a couple of 40-ounce bottles of malt liquor.

headline.main: Tailoring Treatments for Teenage Drug Users

docs.abstract: Levels of teenage drinking and drug abuse remain stubbornly high; many experts say more treatment programs tailored to teenagers are needed; Dr Marc Fishman, psychiatrist and faculty member at Johns Hopkins, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate majority leaders usually set out their legislative goals on the first day of a Congressional session, but when the 108th Congress convenes on Tuesday, Senator Bill Frist, the incoming majority leader, will not be introducing his top 10 bills, his spokesman said today. Republicans in the Senate said today that they simply had not yet had enough time to organize for dealing with the well-prepared Democrats, having been preoccupied for nearly a month with the leadership crisis brought on by their former leader, Senator Trent Lott. They plan a daylong caucus on Wednesday to set priorities, but they acknowledged that their plans would in large part be shaped by President Bush's State of the Union address later this month.

headline.main: The Majority Starts a Step Behind

docs.abstract: Senate's new Republican leadership under Bill Frist scrambles to assemble customary opening agenda of legislation, planning daylong caucus to set priorities while acknowledging that their plans will be shaped in large part by Pres Bush's State of the Union address; photo; likely key measures reviewed (M)

byline.original: By DAVID FIRESTONE and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors announced a 24-count indictment yesterday against an eye doctor who worked in state-regulated adult homes in New York City, charging that he repeatedly took advantage of mentally ill residents by performing unnecessary procedures or billing for treatment that he never provided. The eye doctor, Shaul Debbi, had been a fixture for years in many adult homes for the mentally ill, and residents often described in interviews how they were ordered by administrators at the homes to line up by the dozens to see him. These visits, prosecutors now contend, were at the heart of a scheme by Dr. Debbi to defraud government health care programs.

headline.main: U.S. Indicts Doctor in Fraud At State Homes For Mentally Ill

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors announce 24-count indictment against ophthalmologist Shaul Debbi, who worked in state-regulated adult homes in New York City; charge that he repeatedly took advantage of mentally ill residents by performing unnecessary procedures or billing for treatment that had never been provided; residents of homes said they were lined up to see Dr Debbi, and prosecutors contend these visits were at heart of scheme to defraud government health care programs; indictment says Debbi regularly billed Medicare and Medicaid from 1998 through 2001 for unnecessary procedures; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Translation errors were found to be ''alarmingly common'' in a study published yesterday that examined communication between pediatricians and parents who did not speak English. The study, in the journal Pediatrics, was based on a review of 13 medical encounters that had been recorded for another purpose. Researchers from the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee found an average of 31 errors per encounter, 73 percent of which were judged capable of affecting the care provided.

headline.main: Perils in the Language of Medicine

docs.lead_paragraph: On paper, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the latest entry for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004, has a lot going for him. A seasoned player with experience on the full spectrum of national issues, he is the only Democrat among at least a half-dozen hopefuls who has run for the nomination before.

headline.main: Veteran Lawmaker Is Restyling Himself As Can-Do Candidate

docs.abstract: Fourth article in series 2004: Presidential Prospects profiles Repr Richard Gephardt; photo; biographical information; seasoned Democratic lawmaker raises impressive sums of money and has developed nationwide network of grassroots loyalists from his years of tireless campaigning for House colleagues, which may give him more staying power than he had when he ran in 1988; Gephardt stepped down as House Democratic leader after party setbacks last year, and says Democrats must offer clear alternative to White House proposals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: These are dark days in the City of Light. It is a cruel trick played on those who are not forewarned. Paris is a northern city, on about the same latitude as Seattle and Vancouver. New York, by contrast, sits on a level with Madrid and Naples.

headline.main: Paris Journal; Call It the City of Darkness, and Give It Vitamin D

docs.abstract: When winter comes, Paris's northern position combines with humidity, above-freezing temperatures, absence of fierce winds and location at bottom of basin to rob city of sun and light; daylight arrives well after 8 am and leaves only eight hours later; darkness has such an effect that French government's generous medical insurance program covers medical consultation for those who grow depressed because of waning light of winter; photos (M)
docs.snippet: These are dark days in the City of Light.    It is a cruel trick played on those who are not forewarned. Paris is a northern city, on about the same latitude as Seattle and Vancouver. New York, by contrast, sits on a level with Madrid and Naples.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new year started with a medical crisis that could spread. Surgeons at four West Virginia hospitals began their walkout on New Year's Day, in protest of malpractice insurance costs. Many operations were canceled, and some patients had to be moved out of state for treatment. In Pennsylvania, a similar walkout was only narrowly averted after an 11th-hour intervention by the governor. The problem with medical malpractice is severe. A recent report by the Institute of Medicine estimates that at least 44,000 and as many as 98,000 hospitalized Americans die every year as a result of medical errors. Those figures exceed the number of people who die each year of breast cancer or in car accidents. Clearly, the victims of medical errors and their families deserve compensation. But resolving these cases under current tort law only hampers medical care.

headline.main: Doctors Belong in Hospitals, Not Courtrooms

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Lloyd M Krieger on how to address medical crisis involving medical malpractice and high insurance rates; says it should be more difficult to file malpractice suits and caps should be imposed on excessive awards for pain and suffering; says rather than focusing on rewarding victims and their lawyers, focus should be on changing how doctors are trained, to track and correct errors and mete out punishment; says doctors, hospitals and medical boards should be more proactive, with uniform system for reporting and analyzing medical errors nationwide (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When George W. Bush took the oath of office two years ago, many people doubted that he would ever be able to govern effectively. During the campaign, an unprophetic pundit observed on TV, ''One thing George Bush is going to have trouble asserting when he gets to office is that he's got a mandate for government.'' That unprophetic pundit was me. In the 24 months since Inauguration Day, Mr. Bush has made his own mandate. Today, Mr. Bush is more than a strong president: he dominates his own party in a way that few modern presidents ever have.
docs.abstract: David Frum Op-Ed article holds Pres Bush has made own mandate, dominating his party in way few modern presidents have; notes he has been accepted by all important Republican factions without any public dissent; holds he has been more cautious than Pres Ronald Reagan on economy, far bolder on social issues and has unexpectedly led Republicans into activisim on foreign policy; drawing (M)o
